question.title: Does Google Collections API have an equivalent of the Ruby Enumerable#inject method?

node.contents: Maybe if you told us poor java users what `Enumerable#inject` does...

astNode.text: Maybe if you told us poor java users what `Enumerable#inject` does...

node.contents: I read through the javadoc and couldn't find anything that resembles it.

astNode.text: I read through the javadoc and couldn't find anything that resembles it.

node.contents: I think you'd be a lot better off just writing your own Reducer interface and static reduce method. It's not too hard and it'd at least make your intent clear rather than being a hack.

astNode.text: I think you'd be a lot better off just writing your own Reducer interface and static reduce method. It's not too hard and it'd at least make your intent clear rather than being a hack.

node.contents: Tha't undoubtely true but maybe in this way you couple it with a *should be* optimized approach..

astNode.text: Tha't undoubtely true but maybe in this way you couple it with a *should be* optimized approach..

node.contents: I think that you don't have a exact inject method.. but you can obtain a similar solution by using the transformValues methods supplied

astNode.text: I think that you don't have a exact inject method.. but you can obtain a similar solution by using the transformValues methods supplied

elements.contents: Maps.transformValues(Map<K,V1> fromMap, Function<? super V1,V2> function) List.transform(List<F> fromList, Function<? super F,? extends T> function)

units.rawText: MapstransformValues(Map<K,V1> fromMap, Function<? super V1,V2> function) List.transform(List<F> fromList, Function<? super F,? extends T> function)

node.contents: Of course you'll need a Function class defined ad hoc to work with the passed parameter of the inject:

astNode.text: Of course you'll need a Function class defined ad hoc to work with the passed parameter of the inject:

elements.contents: class MyFunction<Type, Type> { static String variable; Type apply(Type t) { //do whatever you want with t // and storing intermediate result to variable // return same t to make this function work like identity return t; } }

comments.text: //do whatever you want with t // and storing intermediate result to variable // return same t to make this function work like identity return t; } }

node.contents: While it does have certain functional programming elements (Predicate, Function), those were to support specific needs and its core focus is not adding functional programming elements for Java (seeing as how it's terribly verbose currently). See this issue for a bit on that.
